prior_works.title: The Fluid Mechanics of Liquid Democracy
prior_works.authors: Paul Gölz, Andrew S. Kahng, Simon Mackenzie, Ariel D. Procaccia
prior_works.role: Foundational model of transitive delegations and flow-based/fractional interpretations in liquid democracy
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Provided the algorithmic framework for resolving delegation graphs via flows and random-walk style propagation, directly motivating the paper’s fractional perspective and its random-walk delegation rule.

prior_works.title: Optimum Branchings
prior_works.role: Combinatorial and algorithmic foundation for maximum-weight arborescences (branchings)
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Underpins the paper’s Borda-branching methodology by supplying the key combinatorial object (maximum-weight branchings) and optimization tools that Mixed Borda Branching generalizes.

prior_works.title: Forest matrices around the Laplacian matrix
prior_works.authors: Pavel Yu. Chebotarev, Elena V. Agaev
prior_works.role: Modern formulation of the matrix-tree/Markov chain tree theorems connecting stationary distributions and weighted spanning trees
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Provides the Markov chain tree theorem used in the paper to analytically link random-walk stationary distributions with weighted branchings, enabling the equivalence between the two proposed fractional rules.

prior_works.title: The Anatomy of a Large-Scale Hypertextual Web Search Engine
prior_works.role: Canonical random-walk-based ranking (PageRank) and anonymity properties via Markov chains on directed graphs
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Informs the anonymous random-walk delegation rule by grounding it in stationary distributions of Markov chains on delegation graphs, a key pillar of the paper’s approach.

prior_works.title: Cloning in Elections: Possibilities and Impossibilities
prior_works.authors: Edith Elkind, Piotr Faliszewski, Arkadii Slinko
prior_works.role: Core theory of clone-robustness in social choice
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Supplies the conceptual foundation for copy-robustness-type axioms; the paper’s copy-robustness notion extends this resistance-to-copies intuition to the delegation setting.

prior_works.title: The random walk construction of uniform spanning trees and uniform labelled trees
prior_works.role: Bridge between random walks and spanning trees
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Reinforces the paper’s use of random walks to characterize distributions over trees/branchings, a conceptual stepping stone toward proving the equivalence of random-walk and branching-based delegation rules.

prior_works.title: Liquid Democracy: An Algorithmic Perspective
prior_works.authors: Markus Brill, Paul Gölz, Dominik Peters, Ulrike Schmidt-Kraepelin, Niklas Wilkening
prior_works.role: Comprehensive formalization of ranked delegations and axioms (including anonymity and copy-robustness) with baseline rules
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Sets out the ranked-delegation framework and the anonymity vs. copy-robustness tension that the paper addresses, and motivates both Borda-branching and random-walk families as central candidates.

synthesis_narrative: The paper’s core contribution—showing that two ostensibly different fractional delegation rules (a Mixed Borda Branching rule and a Random Walk rule) coincide and bridge an anonymity vs. copy-robustness tension—rests on three intertwined intellectual strands. First, the algorithmic framework of liquid democracy with transitive delegations and fractional/flow-based interpretations, pioneered by Gölz et al., motivates viewing delegation outcomes through probabilistic propagation or flow, which naturally leads to random-walk formulations. Second, the Borda-branching side inherits its combinatorial backbone from Edmonds’ theory of optimum branchings: maximum-weight arborescences offer a principled way to resolve cycles and allocate representation consistent with ranked preferences, and the paper generalizes this via “Mixed” Borda Branching. Third, the bridge between these paradigms is mathematical: the Markov chain tree theorem, in the Chebotarev–Agaev lineage (and conceptually foreshadowed by Aldous’ random-walk constructions of spanning trees), connects stationary distributions of random walks to weighted sums over directed spanning trees/branchings. This allows the authors to equate the random-walk rule (rooted in PageRank-style anonymity) with the branching-based rule (capturing copy-robustness-like behavior). The broader social choice context of clone/copy resistance, crystallized by Elkind–Faliszewski–Slinko, provides the axiomatic lens for assessing copy-robustness, while the survey-level formalization by Brill et al. codifies ranked delegations and the anonymity vs. copy-robustness trade-off that the present paper resolves via fractional rules and a unifying tree-theoretic argument.
